article:
"Everything happens for the best," my mother said whenever I faced disappointment. "   _  you carry on, one day something good will happen.
Mother was right. After graduating from college in 1932, I   _  to try for
a job in radio, then work my way up to a sports announcer. I  _   on the door of every station in Chicago and was refused every
time. In one studio, a kind lady told me that  _  stations
would't hire an inexperienced person and advised me to try in small
stations that  _  give me a chance.
I went to Dixon, Illinois, where a local athlete was   _  to manage its
sports department. Since Dixon was   where   I
had played football, the job  _  just right for
me. So I applied,  _   I wasn't hired.
My disappointment must
have shown. "  _  happens for the best," Mom
reminded me. Dad  _  me the car to hunt for job.
I tried a radio station in Davenport, Iowa. The program director told me they
had  _  hired a sports announcer. I was very
disappointed and asked aloud, "How can a fellow get to be a sports
announcer if he can't get a job in a radio station?"
I was about to go when I heard the   _  calling, "Do you know anything about
football?" Then he stood me  _  a microphone
and asked me to broadcast an imaginary game.
On my   _  home,
I thought of my mother's words: "If you carry on, one day something good
will happen. Something wouldn't have happened without some
disappointments."
